msContents.summary: Muslim b. ìAmr, the sender of this letter, also wrote letter 26 which deals with commercial matters. Muslim seems to have been a colleague of ìAbd All��h in commercial and possibly also administrative matters. The letter contains some elaborate blessings at the beginning of the letter and also uses a more extensive final blessing than the other letters in the corpus.

condition.ab: Light brown papyrus. The original cutting lines have been preserved on all four sides. There are several small holes in the papyrus along a vertical folding line which have caused minimal damage to the text. Recto is written in black ink with a thick pen perpendicular to the fibers, Verso is written parallel to the fibers.

handDesc.p: The letter is carefully executed in a script that shows many exaggerated and labored features of 1st/2nd-7th/8th century script. D��l bends backwards at the top (l. 2 asìad; l. 3 aìmadu; l. 7 dh��lika); final mim has a short tale (l.1 bi-sm; rahim; l.2 muslim; l. 6 umm). There are some diacritical dots.
